Movie 1: Unlisted Demon 101'' # ''[[Konjiki no Gash Bell!! Movie 2: Attack of the Mecha-Vulcan]]'' }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} '''''Zatch Bell!''''', also known in Japan as {{Nihongo|'''''Golden Gash!'''''|金色のガッシュ!!|Konjiki no Gasshu!!}}, is a [[shōnen manga|''shōnen'']] [[manga]] series written and illustrated by [[Makoto Raiku]]. It was published in [[Shogakukan]]'s ''[[Weekly Shōnen Sunday]]''. The series follows [[Kiyo Takamine and Zatch Bell|Kiyo Takamine]] and his {{nihongo|Mamodo|魔物|Mamono|lit. "demon"}} partner [[Kiyo Takamine and Zatch Bell|Zatch Bell]] as they try to win the tournament of Mamodo battles in order to make Zatch the king of the Mamodo world. The manga was later adapted into a 150 episode [[anime]] television series titled {{Nihongo|'''''Golden Gash Bell!!'''''|金色のガッシュベル!!|Konjiki no Gasshu Beru!!}} by [[Toei Animation]]. The anime was directed by Tetsuji Nakamura. ''Konjiki no Gash Bell'' premiered on [[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]] on April 6, 2003 and ran until March 26, 2006. In addition to an array of licensed merchandise, the series also spawned a series of [[List of Zatch Bell! video games|video games]] and two animated films. ==Plot== {{Main article|List of Zatch Bell! characters}} One hundred Demons go to Earth every 1,000 years to battle to be the king of the Demon world. Each Demon needs a human partner in order to use his or her spell book, a book that seals the powers of the Demons. When read aloud, the spells are cast by the Demon producing many effects. If the spell book is burned, the Demon is forced to return to the Demon world, and they lose all claim to the position of the Demon king. While the spells in each book typically are different for each Demon, there are Demon that share spells, like Zatch Bell and his evil twin brother, Zeno Bell. The human and their Demon gain these spells through experience and hard work. The last Demon standing without their book burnt is the new Demon king. The story follows [[Kiyo Takamine and Zatch Bell|Kiyo Takamine]], a 14-year-old boy in junior high school. His father, Seitaro Takamine, discovers an unconscious child named [[Kiyo Takamine and Zatch Bell|Zatch Bell]] while in a forest in England, and sends Zatch to live with Kiyo. Unlike the other Mamodo, Zatch lost his memory of the Mamodo world. Kiyo learns about the spell book when he reads a spell causing Zatch to fire lightning from his mouth (the spell is mentioned in the first episode). As Kiyo and Zatch begin to encounter different Mamodos and learn more about the Mamodo battles, they discover that there are those who do not wish to fight and there are those who fight for the wrong reasons. After meeting a Mamodo named [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Lori and Kolulu|Kolulu]] and seeing how this kind Mamodo was forced to fight due to the power of her spells, Zatch decides to become a kind king in order to stop the battle from ever happening again. As the story progresses, Zatch and Kiyo meet other Mamodos that share similar views to them and become allies. They meet allies such as [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Megumi Oumi and Tia|Megumi Oumi and Tia]] in which they specialize in defensive spells such as different types of shields. Kiyo and Zatch meet [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Parco Folgore and Kanchomé|Folgore and Kanchomé (Canchome)]] who are both comic relief characters and they only have transformation spells such as Kanchomé being able to turn himself really big. Zatch met [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Kafk Sunbeam and Umagon|Kafk Sunbeam and Umagon]] earlier in England. Umagon is a Mamodo who specializes in transformation spells that can put armor around his body. [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Sherry Belmont and Brago|Shery (Sherie) Belmont and Brago]] who was originally Zatch and Kiyo's rival in the series later becomes their allies and he has gravity type spells. As the number of Mamodos decreases, Zatch and his allies encounter a Mamodo called [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Koko and Zofis|Zofis]] who takes control of several Mamodos who were sealed in stone from the previous battle to decide the king. With Kiyo and Zatch needing more allies, they meet [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Dr.Riddles and Kido|Dr. Riddles and Kido]]. They helped teach the main allies how to unlock new spells such as Zatch unlocking the sixth spell. Kiyo and Zatch with friends make their way to South America to fight off Zofis and the thousand year Mamodos. Many characters fell and got their book burned. The most notable one was Kido who was sent back to the Mamodo world after fighting Belgium E.O. Ultimately, Sherry and Brago came to help to fight Zofis. Zofis took control of Sherry's friend Koko who Zofis makes her do evil things such as burning a whole town. Sherry and Brago beat Zofis but not without the help of Kiyo and friends. Sherry gets Koko back to normal and the battle in South America is over. After the battle against Zofis, the whole world is put in danger after a giant Mamodo named [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Faudo|Faudo]] is brought to life by a Mamodo named Riou. Riou was looking for Mamodos that have enough strength to help activate Faudo. So he puts a curse on [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Li-en and Wonrei|Li-en and Wonrei]] who Kiyo and Zatch befriend in the middle of the series. The protagonists make their way to Faudo to try to destroy it and to save their friends. The battle in Faudo was the toughest battle for the characters up to that point in the story. Kiyo almost died against Riou, and many of Zatch's friends got sent back to the Mamodo world such as Wonrei. Faudo is then taken over by a Mamodo that looks like Zatch, who turns out to be Zatch's twin brother [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Dufort and Zeno Bell|Zeno Bell]]. Zatch and Zeno have a big fight inside of Faudo. Through Zeno's flashback, he resented Zatch because their Father King Bell bestowed Zatch the power of Bao, which is Zatch's strongest spell. Zeno at a young age had to train everyday and always got punished while Zatch lived with another family peacefully. Ultimately, Zeno understands Zatch also suffered too and apologizes to what he has done to Zatch. Zeno gets his book burned and is sent back to the Mamodo world. Finally, when the number of Mamodos have decreased to ten, an evil and powerful Mamodo named [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Vino and Clear Note|Clear Note]] appears. With Clear Note's immense strength the protagonists have to train to fight against Clear Note in the King's Festival. The King's Festival is where the final ten Mamodo have to fight to be king. Most notably before the Zatch and Kiyo fought Clear Note, Kanchome got sent back to the Mamodo world when he was ambushed by Clear Note. With Kancome gone before the big fight it Kiyo, Megumi, and Sunbeam vowed to win against Clear Note for Kanchome and Folgore's sake. Past Mamodos who Kiyo and Zatch have encountered in the past came to help out. They helped out in a form of spells because Kiyo's spell book unlocked all of the Mamodo's spells. Kiyo used Kido's strongest spell, Wonrei's strongest spell, and many more spells from their past allies After many sacrifices, Clear Note is defeated leaving Zatch and his ally [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Sherry Belmont and Brago|Brago]] as the remaining Mamodos. After Kiyo's graduation ceremony, Zatch and Brago battle and Zatch is crowned the Mamodo King. For the prize for helping Zatch become king. Kiyo had an option of two prizes: either getting a wish and forgetting about Zatch, or get nothing but keep his memories of Zatch. He chooses the latter option. Three weeks later, a letter is sent from the Mamodos to their human partners. Zatch's letter reveals that all is well in the Mamodo world. ==Production== After Raiku's series in the ''[[Shōnen Sunday Super]]'' ended, Raiku looked at his old drafts he created in the past for an idea for his next series.{{cite book|last=Raiku|first=Makoto|script-title=ja:金色のガッシュ!!|publisher=[[Shogakukan]]|date=May 18, 2001|series=[[Zatch Bell]]|volume=Volume 1|isbn=978-4-09-126231-8|language=Japanese}} One of his ideas was a mercenary who uses a giant sword to defeat enemies. After playing with that idea for three months, Raiku decided to abandon it and go with another idea. His next idea was a story where a middle school student finds an old toy and with the help of a noble knight, combats evil and after taking this up with his agent, he was advised to use a cuter character to fight and thus, [[Kiyo Takamine and Zatch Bell|Zatch]] was created. After Raiku worked on the idea for a few months, it was published. Raiku said that he intended to create a "passionate story about a heartwarming friendship" and that he used the concept as a "base" while adding the mamodo, book, and spell concepts. He was inspired by a western magic story that he read to create Zatch's red spell book. The reason Zatch uses lightning spells because his name had the word "Raiku" means "lightning" in Japanese. He mentions he created [[List of Zatch Bell! characters#Parco Folgore and Kanchomé|Folgore]] with the words "Invincible Italian Man" as a base.{{cite web|url=http://www.zatch-bell.com/index3_skip.html|title=Origins, Creator Q & A|publisher=Viz Media|accessdate=August 19, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100129035235/http://www.zatch-bell.com/index3_skip.html|archivedate=January 29, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}} While writing volume five and six which takes place in England, Raiku went to England on a research trip.{{cite book|last=Raiku|first=Makoto|script-title=ja:金色のガッシュ!!|publisher=[[Shogakukan]]|date=July 18, 2002|series=金色のガッシュ!!|volume=Volume 6|isbn=978-4-09-126236-3|language=Japanese}} ''Zatch Bell!'' ended in December 2007. Shogakukan sent Raiku back his original manga artwork."[http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-06-06/zatch-bell/gash-manga-creator-raiku-sues-shogakukan News: Gash/Zatch Bell Manga Creator Raiku Sues Shogakukan (Updated)]." ''[[Anime News Network]]''. June 6, 2008. Retrieved April 17, 2011. However, five full color pieces were missing."[http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-11-11/gash/zatch-bell-raiku-wins-2.55m-yen-over-lost-art News: Gash/Zatch Bell's Raiku Wins 2.55M Yen over Lost Art (Update)]." ''[[Anime News Network]]''. November 11, 2008. Retrieved April 17, 2011. On May 21, 2008, Raiku announced that he would no longer do business with Shogakukan. During the same year Raiku sued Shogakukan over the lost ''Zatch Bell!''-related artwork. Later that year Raiku settled for 2.55 million yen. The studio in which Makoto Raiku does his series is a unique studio. He has a large collection of autographs from manga artists displayed on the foyer which is the first thing one sees in the building."[http://en.gigazine.net/news/20100803_makoto_raiku_workplace/ Place of Creation: “Zatch Bell!” Manga Artist Makoto Raiku in His Workplace]. " '' [[Gigazine]]''. August 3, 2010. Retrieved November 5, 2015. His studio contains a high ceiling to prevent getting claustrophobic, and he spends all day there for a dead line. Raiku collects figurines and displays them on his wall while he in his studio writing. Raiku does admit that most of his work takes place in a restaurant where he does most of his story boarding. He says there is less distraction since he is just surrounded by people and not games and the internet. Story boarding for a regular chapter of Zatch Bell takes about two days for Raiku to do. When the editor approves of the story board he calls his assistants and they start working. Raiku usually has four assistants but when dead lines are tight he uses a fifth one. Typically, a chapter of Zatch Bell! is released almost every week of the year except for holidays such as Golden Week in Japan, and Christmas. Even during those holidays he has to constantly think about the story and have new ideas. ==Media== ===Manga=== {{Main article|List of Zatch Bell! chapters}} Written and drawn by Makoto Raiku, ''Konjiki no Gash!'' premiered in [[Shogakukan]]'s [[Weekly Shōnen Sunday]] magazine in January, 2001. In December 2005, the series was put on hiatus due to the author injuring his hand.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2005-12-08/zatch-bell-on-hiatus|title=Zatch Bell on Hiatus|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=August 19, 2009}} The series resumed its serialization on issue No. 11 of ''Weekly Shōnen Sunday'' in February 2006.[Gash Bell resumes Serialization]{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2006-02-20/konjiki-no-gash-resumes-serialization|title=Konjiki no Gash Resumes Serialization|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=August 19, 2009}} The series finished its serialization on December 26, 2008 with 323 installments.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-12-28/zatch-bell-manga-ends-after-7-years-323-installments|title=Zatch Bell Manga Ends After 7 Years, 323 Installments|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=August 19, 2009}} The [[manga]] spanned a total of 323 individual chapters and 33 ''[[tankōbon]]'' volumes.{{cite web|url=http://skygarden.shogakukan.co.jp/skygarden/owa/solc_dtl?isbn=4091262317|script-title=ja:小学館: コミック 「金色のガッシュ!! 1」|trans-title=Zatch Bell! Vol. 1|publisher=[[Shogakukan]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=June 28, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://skygarden.shogakukan.co.jp/skygarden/owa/solc_dtl?isbn=9784091213990|script-title=ja:小学館: コミック 「金色のガッシュ!! 33」|trans-title=Zatch Bell! Vol. 33|publisher=[[Shogakukan]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=June 28, 2009}} The series was licensed for an English language release by [[Viz Media]]. The first volume of the series was released on September 15, 2004{{cite web|url=http://www.viz.com/products/products.php?product_id=2372|title=Zatch Bell! Vol. 1|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|accessdate=June 28, 2009}} Viz has discontinued the series, however, having released 33 volumes by June 2, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.viz.com/products/products.php?product_id=7592|title=Zatch Bell! Vol. 25|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|accessdate=June 28, 2009}} In March 2011, Makoto Raiku released a one-shot chapter of Zatch Bell to promote the rerelease of the manga in a new bunkouban format.{{cite web|title=Gash/Zatch Bell Gets New 1-Shot Manga in March|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2011-02-10/gash/zatch-bell-gets-new-1-shot-manga-in-march|accessdate=May 29, 2011}} ===Anime=== {{Main article|List of Zatch Bell! episodes}} The episodes of the ''Zatch Bell!'' [[anime]] series were directed by Tetsuji Nakamura and Yukio Kaizawa and produced by [[Toei Animation]].{{cite web|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iHDWSbM8?url=http://www.toei-anim.co.jp/tv/GB/staff.html|archivedate=July 15, 2009|url=http://www.toei-anim.co.jp/tv/GB/staff.html|title=''Konjiki no Gash Bell!!'' staff list|publisher=[[Toei Animation]]|accessdate=July 14, 2009}} The episodes were aired on [[Fuji Television]] between April 6, 2003 to March 26, 2006 and spanned 150 episodes.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iHCuKgBr?url=http://www.toei-anim.co.jp/tv/GB/episode/list/|archivedate=July 15, 2009|url=http://www.toei-anim.co.jp/tv/GB/episode/list/|title=''Konjiki no Gash Bell!!'' episode list|publisher=[[Toei Animation]]|accessdate=July 14, 2009}} [[Viz Media]] obtained the foreign television, home video, and merchandising rights to the ''Zatch Bell!'' anime from Toei Studio on August 4, 2005.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j9XnfOMV?url=http://www.viz.com/news/newsroom/2005/08_zatchbell.php|archivedate=August 19, 2009|url=http://www.viz.com/news/newsroom/2005/08_zatchbell.php|title=Viz Media to releases Manga & Anime Series for Zatch Bell!|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|accessdate=August 19, 2009}} Subsequently, Viz Media contracted [[Studiopolis]] to create the English adaptation of the anime. The North American English dub has been edited and localized for young children aged 6 to 10 years in America. Viz Media has licensed its individual ''Zatch Bell!'' merchandising rights to several different companies, including a new toy line made by Mattel and a [[Zatch Bell! The Card Battle|collectible card game]] released by [[Bandai]] in the United States and Japan.{{cite web|url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/6458.html|title=Bandai's 'Zatch Bell! TCG'| publisher=icv2.com|accessdate=August 19, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/7370.html|title=Zatch Bell Apparel License Granted| publisher=icv2.com|accessdate=August 19, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/7295.html|title=Mattel Plans Full Zatch Bell Line| publisher=icv2.com|accessdate=August 19, 2009}} The English adaptation of the ''Zatch Bell!'' anime premiered on Cartoon Network's [[Toonami]] on March 5, 2005 to January 20, 2007 with seventy-seven episodes aired. Canada's [[YTV (TV channel)|YTV]] began airing ''Zatch Bell!'' in September 2005 and ended on December 6, 2008 with episode 104.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j9YqoQ4m?url=http://www.viz.com/news/newsroom/2005/08_zatch_ytv.php|archivedate=August 19, 2009|url=http://www.viz.com/news/newsroom/2005/08_zatch_ytv.php|title=Viz Media to releases Manga & Anime Series for Zatch Bell!|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|accessdate=August 19, 2009}} The series was released in fifty-one DVD compilations by [[Shogakukan]] between November 19, 2003 and March 7, 2007 in Japan.{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B0000DJWHO/ | script-title=ja:金色のガッシュベル!! 1 | publisher = Amazon.com | language = Japanese | accessdate =June 12, 2009}}{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B000LW7L54/ | title = 金色のガッシュベル!! Level-3 17 | publisher = Amazon.com | language = Japanese | accessdate =June 12, 2009}} As of July 2009, Thirteen DVD compilations of the English adaption of the anime have been released by Viz Media between November 8, 2005 and December 4, 2007.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000ALM4KI/ |title=Zatch Bell!, Vol. 1: The Lightning Boy From Another World (2005)|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=July 14, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000T28G4G/ |title=Zatch Bell! – Vol. 13|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=July 14, 2009}} All the Viz Media home releases of Zatch Bell show only the North American edited English dub episodes and they are rated A for All Ages. New Video released a DVD box set, "''Zatch Bell!: The Complete Seasons 1 & 2''", on December 3, 2013 that included the first 100 episodes of the North American edited English dub.https://www.amazon.com/Zatch-Bell-Collection/dp/B00E68991S/ref=sr_1_16?ie=UTF8&qid=1374954565&sr=8-16&keywords=zatch+bell+dvd On June 22, 2017, [[Starz]] announced that they would be offering episodes of the series for their Video on Demand service starting July 1, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/861323-starz-app-july-2017-movies-and-tv-titles-announced|title=Starz app July 2017 Movies and TV Titles Announced|date=June 22, 2017|publisher=ComingSoon.net|accessdate=September 13, 2018}} Every country outside of Japan (even Italy) airs and adapts the show from the North American edited English dub. ===Films=== The series spawned two films. The first film, {{Nihongo3|lit. "Movie Golden Gash Bell!! Unlisted demon #101"|劇場版 金色のガッシュベル！！ 「１０１番目の魔物」|"Gekijou Ban Konjiki no Gash Bell!! 101 Banme no Mamono"}}, was released in Japanese theaters on August 7, 2004 and released on DVD on December 15, 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2004-03-09/trailers|title=Trailers!| publisher=Anime News Network|accessdate=August 19, 2009}}{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B0006A9J60/ | title = 劇場版「金色のガッシュベル!!101番目の魔物」 [DVD] | publisher = Amazon.co.jp | language = Japanese | accessdate =August 19, 2009}} The movie tells the story of a mamodo named Wiseman who steals a mysterious white spell book in order to participate in the Mamodo battles in order to become the Mamodo King. Realizing his evil intentions if he becomes King, Kiyo, Zatch, and their comrades begun their battle against Wiseman. The second film, {{Nihongo3|lit. "Movie Golden Gash Bell!! Attack of the Mechavulcan"|劇場版 金色のガッシュベル！！ 「メカバルカンの来襲」|"Gekijou Ban [[Konjiki no Gash Bell!! Mecabarukan no raishuu]]"}}, was released in Japanese theaters on August 6, 2005 and on DVD on January 2, 2006.{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B000BNFIEY/ | title = 劇場版 金色のガッシュベル!! メカバルカンの来襲 [DVD] | publisher = Amazon.co.jp | language = Japanese | accessdate =August 19, 2009}} The movie tells the story of Dr. M2 who travels from the future mamodo world to the human world with his army of mechanical Vulcan 300 look-alikes. Both films were released exclusively in Japan until March 27, 2018, when Discotek Media brought both movies to [[Blu-ray]] in North America. The titles were localized to ''Zatch Bell!: 101st Devil'' and ''Zatch Bell!: Attack of Mechavulcan'', and contained the original Japanese audio with English subtitles.https://twitter.com/discotekmedia/status/952601441994145792 Each movie is to also get an individual DVD release on April 24th https://twitter.com/discotekmedia/status/969000798595117056. ===CDs=== {{Unreferenced section|date=October 2009}} The ''Konjiki no Gash Bell'' soundtracks were composed by [[Kow Otani]]. The first [[Soundtrack|Original Soundtrack]] was released in Japan on August 27, 2003 which contained 25 tracks. The second Original Soundtrack was released on January 7, 2004 and also contained 25 tracks. The third and last Original Soundtrack of the anime was released on March 24, 2006 and contained 28 tracks. The first movie Original Soundtrack titled ''Gekijôban Konjiki no Gash Bell!! 101-banme no mamono Original Sound Track'' was released on September 26, 2004 and contained 36 tracks. The second movie Original Soundtrack titled ''Gekijôban Konjiki no Gash Bell!! Mecha-Vulcan Strikes Back Original Sound Track'' was released on August 3, 2006 and contained 27 tracks. ''Konjiki no Gash Bell-Collection of Golden Songs'' was released on March 24, 2004. It contained the most popular character songs from the first season of the anime. ''Collection of Golden Songs 2'' was released on February 23, 2005 which contained character songs from the second season of the anime. ''Collection of Golden Songs 3'' was released on February 22, 2006 and contained character songs from the third season of the anime. Other CDs including character singles, character song series and character song duet series were released during the period the anime ran. ===Video games=== {{Main article|List of Zatch Bell! video games}} ==Reception== In 2003, the manga won the [[Shogakukan Manga Award]] for best shōnen title of the year.{{cite web|url=http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |script-title=ja:小学館漫画賞：歴代受賞者 |publisher=Shogakukan |language=Japanese |accessdate=August 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929094941/http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |archivedate=September 29, 2007 }} The ''Konjiki no Gash Bell!!'' anime ranked twentieth in animage's anime popularity poll in 2005.{{cite web|title=トップ ＞ 第28回アニメグランプリ　［2006年6月号］（現在位置）|url=http://animage.jp/gp_new/index.html|date=June 2006|publisher=[[Animage]]|accessdate=August 11, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019171753/http://animage.jp/gp_new/index.html|archivedate=October 19, 2010|df=mdy-all}} The anime ranked 64th of the Top 100 anime in 2005 according to a web poll conducted by [[TV Asahi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2005-09-23/tv-asahi-top-100-anime-part-2|title=TV Asahi Top 100 Anime|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=August 19, 2009}} Mania.com's Jarred Pine's review of the first volume said that the art style was odd yet crude. He also mentioned the art style and explosive action scenes with moments of humor save the series from being recycled material.{{cite web|url=http://www.mania.com/zatch-bell-aka-konjiki-gash-vol-01_article_82272.html|title=Zatch Bell (aka: Konjiki no Gash!!) Vol. #01|last=Pine|first=Jarred|publisher=Mania.com|date=August 11, 2005|accessdate=July 21, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jifIAyFr?url=http://www.mania.com/zatch-bell-aka-konjiki-gash-vol-01_article_82272.html|archivedate=September 11, 2009|df=mdy-all}} [[Anime News Network]]'s Zac Bertschy review of the anime adaption described it as "...mind-numbingly over-the-top, so enthusiastically bizarre, that it's difficult to not get sucked into its strange little world" but criticized how it was like a "battle your way to the top while learning important lessons about teamwork and courage" anime. He commented how the "sheer exuberance and energy" saves the show from being a bland anime and how it would be the perfect show for kids.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/zatch-bell/dvd-1|title=Zatch Bell – DVD 1 review|last=Bertschy|first=Zac|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=July 21, 2009}} IGN's review of the series was mostly negative. IGN's Jason Van Horn criticized the animation, plot, and dubbed voice acting.{{cite web|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/753/753103p4.html|title=Anime Worth Your Time|last=Horn|first=Jason Van|date=January 8, 2007|publisher=[[IGN]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} IGN's JKB stated the books are more interesting than the animation.{{cite web|url=http://comics.ign.com/articles/649/649091p1.html|title=Zatch Bell Vol. 1 & 2 Review|date=September 8, 2005|publisher=[[IGN]]|accessdate=July 21, 2009}} Common Sense Media describes the story as "isn't just about violence"."[https://www.commonsensemedia.org/tv-reviews/zatch-bell Zatch Bell! TV Review]. " '' [[Common Sense Media]]''. November 15, 2009. Retrieved November 8, 2015. They also say that there is always challenges, adversities, and questions of identity that the characters face especially Zatch and Kiyo. They compliment how the characters often think aloud when talking about their painful experiences or flashbacks. They applaud on how each of the characters problems in the series are not far off on what kids deal with today. They criticized how the battles uses visuals, languages, sound effects, and dramatic effects that often get drawn out and sometimes become hard to watch. Overall, they said with the graphic violence and the internal struggles that the different characters face throughout the series some parents may not find Zatch Bell! appropriate for their children under ten years old. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Portal|Anime and manga|2000s|Comedy}} ;English *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.zatch-bell.com/ |date=* |title=''Zatch Bell!'' website }} *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.viz.com/properties/zatchbell/ |date=* |title=''Zatch Bell'' }} at [[VIZ Media]] *{{ann|manga|4597}} *{{ann|anime|2290}} *[https://www.starz.com/series/32324/episodes/info ''Zatch Bell!''] Starz website ;Japanese *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050227044721/http://www.websunday.net/gash/ Shonen Sunday ''Konjiki no Gash Bell!!'' website] *[http://www.toei-anim.co.jp/tv/GB/ Toei ''Konjiki no Gash Bell!!'' website] *[http://www.fujitv.co.jp/b_hp/gasshu/ Fuji TV “Konjiki no Gash Bell!!'' website] {{Zatch Bell navigation}} {{Weekly Shōnen Sunday - 2000–2009}} {{Shogakukan Manga Award - Shōnen}} {{Toonami-anime}} [[Category:Zatch Bell!| ]] [[Category:2001 manga]] [[Category:2003 anime television series]] [[Category:Anime series based on manga]] [[Category:Adventure anime and manga]] [[Category:Comedy anime and manga]] [[Category:Europe in fiction]] [[Category:Fuji Television shows]] [[Category:Manga adapted into films]] [[Category:Shogakukan manga]] [[Category:Shōnen manga]] [[Category:Shows on Toonami Jetstream]] [[Category:Toei Animation television]] [[Category:Toonami]] [[Category:TVB]] [[Category:Viz Media anime]] [[Category:Viz Media manga]] [[Category:Winners of the Shogakukan Manga Award for shōnen manga]]
